channel.title: NPR Topics: Science
channel.description: The latest health and science news. Updates on medicine, healthy living, nutrition, drugs, diet, and advances in science and technology. Subscribe to the Health & Science podcast.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: Why do humans kiss?
item.description: Matilda Brindle, an evolutionary biologist at the University of Oxford, explains.
item.content:encoded: Matilda Brindle, an evolutionary biologist at the University of Oxford, explains.
item.dc:creator: Emily Kwong

item.title: Four people on NASA'S Crew-12 arrive at the International Space Station
item.description: The crew will spend the next eight months conducting experiments to prepare for human exploration beyond Earth's orbit.
item.content:encoded:
The crew will spend the next eight months conducting experiments to prepare for human exploration beyond Earth's orbit.

(Image credit: NASA)
item.dc:creator: Lydia Calitri

item.title: What monogamy in the animal world tells us about ourselves
item.description: As Valentine's Day approaches, we take a look at monogamy and its alternatives among animals — including humans.
item.content:encoded: As Valentine's Day approaches, we take a look at monogamy and its alternatives among animals — including humans.
item.dc:creator: Katia Riddle

item.title: What elephant whiskers can teach us about touch
item.description: Elephants use their trunks much like a human uses their hands: to pick up food and manipulate objects. A new study finds that tiny, specialized whiskers on elephant trunks help them do it.
item.content:encoded: Elephants use their trunks much like a human uses their hands: to pick up food and manipulate objects. A new study finds that tiny, specialized whiskers on elephant trunks help them do it.
item.dc:creator: Nathan Rott

item.title: On their way! 4 people on NASA Crew-12 mission launch to International Space Station
item.description: The four are set to dock with the space station on Saturday, returning the orbital lab to its full complement of seven. NASA's last mission, Crew-11, left a month early due to an ill crew member.
item.content:encoded:
The four are set to dock with the space station on Saturday, returning the orbital lab to its full complement of seven. NASA's last mission, Crew-11, left a month early due to an ill crew member.

(Image credit: SpaceX via NASA)
item.dc:creator: Russell Lewis

item.title: Have astronomers witnessed the birth of a black hole?
item.description: A massive star in the nearby Andromeda galaxy has simply disappeared. Some astronomers believe that it's collapsed in on itself and formed a black hole.
item.content:encoded: A massive star in the nearby Andromeda galaxy has simply disappeared. Some astronomers believe that it's collapsed in on itself and formed a black hole.
item.dc:creator: Nell Greenfieldboyce

item.title: A researcher's effort to make edible cotton seeds
item.description: Edible cotton seeds could revolutionize the cotton industry. That's the goal of one researcher who says the seeds would be an inexpensive protein source that could help feed millions of people.
item.content:encoded: Edible cotton seeds could revolutionize the cotton industry. That's the goal of  one researcher who says the seeds would be an inexpensive protein source that could help feed millions of people.
item.dc:creator: Michael Marks

item.title: An ape, a tea party — and the ability to imagine
item.description: The ability to imagine — to play pretend — has long been thought to be unique to humans. A new study suggests one of our closest living relatives can do it too.
item.content:encoded: The ability to imagine — to play pretend — has long been thought to be unique to humans. A new study suggests one of our closest living relatives can do it too.
item.dc:creator: Nathan Rott

item.title: This complex brain network may explain many of Parkinson's stranger symptoms
item.description: Parkinson's disease appears to disrupt a brain network involved in everything from movement to memory.
item.content:encoded:
'/>

Parkinson's disease appears to disrupt a brain network involved in everything from movement to memory.

(Image credit: Sara Moser)
item.dc:creator: Jon Hamilton

item.title: US scientists adapt after the Trump administration's funding blows
item.description: Scientists say the Trump administration's policies have led to major changes and uncertainty about scientific efforts and accomplishments.
item.content:encoded: Scientists say the Trump administration's policies have led to major changes and uncertainty about scientific efforts and accomplishments.
item.dc:creator: Kate Grumke
